narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: KNowledge of the various approaches to responding to disagreement. Some of the major challenges to those positions, and how those positions apply to a variety of types of cases, notably religious and moral disagreement.

I learned how to better think about how to rationally respond to disagreement and other higher order evidence and was introduced to the ideas of the most influential contemporary philosophers on the subject.

Understanding of how modern epistemology handles disagreement by equally qualified individuals; how disagreement ought to be treated in terms of being evidence; how religious disagreement may or may not be a special case of general disagreement.
How to respond to disagreement, how to think about higher-order evidence, what epistemology should aim for, what the limits of rationality are.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Fascinating content that made me genuinely reflect on how I should respond to disagreement and actually thus led me to change my beliefs about certain things; Readings are all excellent, clear, and selected in such a way to build off each other which is really helpful; Prof. Pittard is excellent in seminar and office hours at raising important questions and being able to have a real back and forth, both clarifying misunderstandings but also challenging (not in a harsh way) arguments put forth by students; reading responses were effective at making students clarify their thoughts while also not being overwhelming amounts of work.
Weaknesses: Sometimes class discussion got a little sidetracked, but this is somewhat to be expected when talking about really charged topics.
This is a great class! I really like the whole setup.

This is a great course. I thought the mix of reading responses, perusall assignments, and final essay was near perfect. The professor might consider having two shorter seminars over the course of the week rather than one long seminar, though -- often it was difficult to maintain a clear dialectic over the course of a seminar, and I would have appreciated more mini-lectures at the beginnings of seminars.

The course is well organized and the syllabus is constructed in a well thought out manner. As with most seminar courses, discussions were rarely able to cover the extent of the readings, but Professor Pittard does a good job of ensuring that the key points are covered. It is a very niche but interesting topic as well which will have one reading many modern philosophy papers. Overall Professor Pittard is a great resource--he's definitely very knowledgeable on the subject, having written a book on it among other things.

Excellent course. Strengths: great syllabus, helpful explanations about content that was sometimes quite dense, a lot of feedback. I can't really think of any cons -- possibly, there could have been more intervention to prevent students from going off-topic during seminar.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It has both opened my eyes to the hidden difficulties and complexities in responding to disagreement and made me re-evaluate how I should do so. This is both practically important given the prevalence of disagreement, but also is intellectually and theoretically engaging, as the abstract questions are interesting and one feels some pressure to try to resolve them due to their practical significance.
Absolutely! It was a very interesting topic in philosophy which you are unlikely to see elsewhere.
I would. It was refreshing and interesting to take a philosophy class focussed on one question, especially a question everyone ought to have a stake in.

It's a good class if you're interested in a very niche subfield of modern epistemology. It focuses almost exclusively on disagreement and modern topics. If you're interested in the topic, take it. If not, maybe try a survey class.
